information_side.text_content: How do you connect to a remote server via SSH?

answer_side.text_content:
ssh username@hostname

Examples:
ssh user@192.168.1.100
ssh user@server.example.com
ssh -p 2222 user@server.com  (custom port)
ssh -i ~/.ssh/private_key user@server.com  (with key)

information_side.text_content: How do you copy files to a remote server?

answer_side.text_content:
scp (Secure Copy)

Examples:
scp file.txt user@server:/path/  (copy to remote)
scp user@server:/path/file.txt ./  (copy from remote)
scp -r directory/ user@server:/path/  (copy directory)
scp -P 2222 file.txt user@server:/path/  (custom port)

information_side.text_content: What command tests network connectivity to a host?

answer_side.text_content:
ping hostname

Examples:
ping google.com
ping 192.168.1.1
ping -c 4 google.com  (send 4 packets only)
ping6 ipv6.google.com  (IPv6 ping)

Use Ctrl+C to stop continuous ping

information_side.text_content: How do you mount a Samba/CIFS share?

answer_side.text_content:
mount -t cifs //server/share /mnt/point -o username=user

Example:
mount -t cifs //192.168.1.100/shared /mnt/shared -o username=john,password=pass

Permanent mount in /etc/fstab:
//server/share /mnt/point cifs username=user,password=pass 0 0

information_side.text_content: What file contains hostname-to-IP mappings?

answer_side.text_content:
/etc/hosts

Format: IP_address hostname [aliases]

Example entries:
127.0.0.1 localhost
192.168.1.100 server.local server
::1 localhost ip6-localhost

This file is checked before DNS resolution.

information_side.text_content: How do you generate SSH key pairs?

answer_side.text_content:
ssh-keygen

Examples:
ssh-keygen  (default RSA key)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519  (Ed25519 key, recommended)
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096  (4096-bit RSA key)
ssh-keygen -f ~/.ssh/mykey  (custom filename)

Keys stored in ~/.ssh/ directory

information_side.text_content: How do you copy your SSH public key to a remote server?

answer_side.text_content:
ssh-copy-id user@server

Alternatively:
cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh user@server 'cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys'

Or manually:
scp ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub user@server:~/.ssh/authorized_keys

Ensures passwordless SSH authentication

information_side.text_content: What command shows active network connections?

answer_side.text_content:
netstat or ss (newer)

Examples:
netstat -tuln  (all listening ports)
netstat -anp  (all connections with process info)
ss -tuln  (listening ports, faster than netstat)
ss -anp  (all connections with processes)

-t: TCP, -u: UDP, -l: listening, -n: numeric

information_side.text_content: How do you download files from the internet?

answer_side.text_content:
wget or curl

wget examples:
wget http://example.com/file.zip
wget -O newname.zip http://example.com/file.zip

curl examples:
curl -O http://example.com/file.zip
curl -o newname.zip http://example.com/file.zip
curl -L url  (follow redirects)

information_side.text_content: How do you mount an NFS share?

answer_side.text_content:
mount -t nfs server:/path /mnt/point

Examples:
mount -t nfs 192.168.1.100:/shared /mnt/nfs
mount -t nfs4 server.com:/export /mnt/nfs4

Permanent in /etc/fstab:
server:/path /mnt/point nfs defaults 0 0

Requires nfs-utils package installed

information_side.text_content: How do you configure a static IP address in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Methods vary by distribution:

Ubuntu/Debian (netplan):
/etc/netplan/01-config.yaml

CentOS/RHEL:
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0

Generic method:
ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0
ip route add default via 192.168.1.1

Persistent: edit /etc/network/interfaces or use NetworkManager

information_side.text_content: What command shows the routing table?

answer_side.text_content:
Multiple commands:

ip route show  (modern, preferred)
route -n  (traditional, numeric)
netstat -rn  (also shows routing table)
ip route  (short form)

Add routes:
ip route add 192.168.2.0/24 via 192.168.1.1
route add -net 192.168.2.0/24 gw 192.168.1.1

Delete routes:
ip route del 192.168.2.0/24

information_side.text_content: How do you test connectivity to a specific port on a remote host?

answer_side.text_content:
Several methods:

telnet hostname port
telnet 192.168.1.100 80

nc (netcat):
nc -zv hostname port
nc -zv 192.168.1.100 22

nmap:
nmap -p 80 hostname
nmap -p 22-80 192.168.1.100

timeout 5 bash -c '</dev/tcp/host/port'  (bash only)

-z: scan only, -v: verbose

information_side.text_content: How do you configure DNS servers in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Edit /etc/resolv.conf:
nameserver 8.8.8.8
nameserver 8.8.4.4
search example.com

Systemd-resolved systems:
systemd-resolve --set-dns=8.8.8.8 --interface=eth0

NetworkManager:
nmcli con mod connection_name ipv4.dns "8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4"

Note: /etc/resolv.conf may be overwritten by DHCP or NetworkManager

information_side.text_content: What command creates an SSH tunnel for port forwarding?

answer_side.text_content:
ssh with port forwarding options:

Local forwarding:
ssh -L 8080:localhost:80 user@server
(forwards local port 8080 to server's port 80)

Remote forwarding:
ssh -R 8080:localhost:80 user@server
(forwards server's port 8080 to local port 80)

Dynamic forwarding (SOCKS proxy):
ssh -D 1080 user@server

-N: no remote command, -f: background

information_side.text_content: How do you share a directory using Samba?

answer_side.text_content:
Configure /etc/samba/smb.conf:

[shared]
  path = /path/to/share
  browseable = yes
  writable = yes
  guest ok = no
  valid users = username

Commands:
sudo smbpasswd -a username  (add samba user)
sudo systemctl restart smbd nmbd
testparm  (test configuration)
smbclient -L localhost  (list shares)

information_side.text_content: What command traces the network path to a destination?

answer_side.text_content:
traceroute or tracepath

Examples:
traceroute google.com
traceroute 8.8.8.8
tracepath google.com  (doesn't require root)
traceroute6 ipv6.google.com  (IPv6)
mtr google.com  (combines ping and traceroute)

Windows equivalent: tracert

Shows each hop (router) between source and destination with timing information.

information_side.text_content: How do you configure a basic firewall using iptables?

answer_side.text_content:
Basic iptables commands:

# Allow SSH
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT

# Allow HTTP/HTTPS
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT
iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT

# Allow established connections
iptables -A INPUT -m state --state ESTABLISHED,RELATED -j ACCEPT

# Drop all other incoming
iptables -P INPUT DROP

# Save rules
iptables-save > /etc/iptables/rules.v4

information_side.text_content: How do you perform DNS lookups and troubleshooting?

answer_side.text_content:
DNS lookup tools:

nslookup google.com
dig google.com
dig @8.8.8.8 google.com  (specific DNS server)
dig google.com MX  (mail records)
dig google.com NS  (name servers)
host google.com
resolvectl query google.com  (systemd-resolved)

Reverse lookup:
dig -x 8.8.8.8
nslookup 8.8.8.8

dig is preferred over nslookup for scripting

information_side.text_content: How do you set up a basic HTTP server for file sharing?

answer_side.text_content:
Quick HTTP servers:

Python 3:
python3 -m http.server 8000
python3 -m http.server 8080 --bind 192.168.1.100

Python 2:
python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000

Node.js (if installed):
npx http-server

BusyBox:
busybox httpd -f -p 8000

Apache/Nginx for production use. These serve files from current directory.

information_side.text_content: How do you configure and manage network interfaces?

answer_side.text_content:
Modern tools:

ip link show  (list interfaces)
ip link set eth0 up  (bring interface up)
ip link set eth0 down  (bring interface down)
ip addr show eth0  (show IP addresses)
ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0

Legacy tools:
ifconfig  (show all interfaces)
ifconfig eth0 up/down
ifup eth0 / ifdown eth0

NetworkManager:
nmcli device status
nmcli connection show

information_side.text_content: How do you set up an FTP server in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Install and configure vsftpd:

sudo apt install vsftpd  (Ubuntu/Debian)
sudo yum install vsftpd  (CentOS/RHEL)

Edit /etc/vsftpd.conf:
local_enable=YES
write_enable=YES
chroot_local_user=YES

sudo systemctl start vsftpd
sudo systemctl enable vsftpd

Create FTP user:
sudo useradd -m ftpuser
sudo passwd ftpuser

Connect: ftp server_ip

information_side.text_content: What commands show network interface statistics and traffic?

answer_side.text_content:
Network statistics commands:

ip -s link  (interface statistics)
cat /proc/net/dev  (raw interface stats)
netstat -i  (interface statistics)
iftop  (real-time traffic by connection)
nload  (real-time bandwidth usage)
bmon  (bandwidth monitor)
sar -n DEV 1  (network stats every second)
ss -s  (socket statistics summary)
watch -n 1 'cat /proc/net/dev'  (continuous monitoring)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure a VPN connection using OpenVPN?

answer_side.text_content:
OpenVPN client setup:

Install: sudo apt install openvpn

Connect with config file:
sudo openvpn --config client.ovpn

Background connection:
sudo openvpn --config client.ovpn --daemon

Systemd service:
sudo cp client.ovpn /etc/openvpn/client.conf
sudo systemctl start openvpn@client
sudo systemctl enable openvpn@client

Check connection:
ip route | grep tun

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network bonding/teaming for redundancy?

answer_side.text_content:
Network bonding setup:

Load bonding module:
sudo modprobe bonding

Create bond interface:
echo '+bond0' > /sys/class/net/bonding_masters

Set bonding mode:
echo 'active-backup' > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/mode

Add slave interfaces:
echo '+eth0' > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/slaves
echo '+eth1' > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/slaves

Configure IP:
ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev bond0
ip link set bond0 up

information_side.text_content: What commands help troubleshoot network performance issues?

answer_side.text_content:
Network performance tools:

ping -f hostname  (flood ping)
iperf3 -c server_ip  (bandwidth test)
iperf3 -s  (start iperf server)
ethtool eth0  (interface capabilities/stats)
ethtool -S eth0  (detailed interface statistics)
ss -tuln  (listening sockets)
lsof -i  (network connections by process)
tcpdump -i eth0  (packet capture)
wireshark  (GUI packet analyzer)
mtr --report hostname  (network path analysis)

information_side.text_content: How do you set up a simple DHCP server?
How do you configure SSH key-based authentication?

answer_side.text_content:
SSH key authentication setup:

1. Generate key pair:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "user@hostname"

2. Copy public key to server:
ssh-copy-id user@server

3. Or manually:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | ssh user@server 'mkdir -p ~/.ssh && cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys'

4. Set permissions on server:
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

5. Disable password auth in /etc/ssh/sshd_config:
PasswordAuthentication no

information_side.text_content: What are common network troubleshooting steps in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Network troubleshooting workflow:

1. Check physical connectivity:
ip link show  (interface status)
ethtool eth0  (link detection)

2. Check IP configuration:
ip addr show
ip route show

3. Test local connectivity:
ping 127.0.0.1  (loopback)
ping gateway_ip

4. Test DNS:
nslookup google.com
dig google.com

5. Check services:
ss -tuln  (listening services)
systemctl status networking

6. Check logs:
journalctl -u NetworkManager
tail /var/log/syslog

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network bridges for virtualization?

answer_side.text_content:
Network bridge setup:

Install bridge utilities:
sudo apt install bridge-utils

Create bridge:
sudo brctl addbr br0
sudo brctl addif br0 eth0
sudo ip link set dev br0 up
sudo ip link set dev eth0 up

Configure IP on bridge:
sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev br0
sudo ip route add default via 192.168.1.1

Modern method with ip command:
sudo ip link add br0 type bridge
sudo ip link set eth0 master br0

Show bridge info:
brctl show
bridge link

information_side.text_content: How do you configure VLAN interfaces in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
VLAN configuration:

Install VLAN support:
sudo apt install vlan
sudo modprobe 8021q

Create VLAN interface:
sudo ip link add link eth0 name eth0.100 type vlan id 100
sudo ip link set dev eth0.100 up
sudo ip addr add 192.168.100.10/24 dev eth0.100

Legacy method:
sudo vconfig add eth0 100
sudo ifconfig eth0.100 192.168.100.10/24 up

Persistent: add to /etc/network/interfaces or use NetworkManager

information_side.text_content: What commands manage wireless networking in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Wireless network tools:

Scan for networks:
sudo iwlist scan
sudo iw dev wlan0 scan | grep SSID

Connect to network:
sudo iwconfig wlan0 essid "NetworkName" key "password"

Modern tools:
nmcli dev wifi list
nmcli dev wifi connect "SSID" password "password"

Low-level tools:
wpa_supplicant  (WPA/WPA2 authentication)
iw  (modern wireless configuration)
wireless-tools  (legacy iwconfig, iwlist)

Check status:
iwconfig wlan0

information_side.text_content: How do you set up port forwarding with iptables?

answer_side.text_content:
Port forwarding with iptables:

Enable IP forwarding:
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
# Make permanent in /etc/sysctl.conf: net.ipv4.ip_forward=1

NAT rule (external to internal):
iptables -t nat -A PREROUTING -p tcp --dport 8080 -j DNAT --to-destination 192.168.1.100:80

Masquerade for outbound:
iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE

Allow forwarding:
iptables -A FORWARD -p tcp -d 192.168.1.100 --dport 80 -j ACCEPT

information_side.text_content: How do you configure a network proxy in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Proxy configuration methods:

Environment variables:
export http_proxy=http://proxy.company.com:8080
export https_proxy=http://proxy.company.com:8080
export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,*.local

System-wide in /etc/environment:
http_proxy=http://proxy.company.com:8080
https_proxy=http://proxy.company.com:8080

APT proxy (/etc/apt/apt.conf):
Acquire::http::Proxy "http://proxy.company.com:8080";

Curl/wget:
curl --proxy http://proxy.company.com:8080 url
wget --proxy=on url

information_side.text_content: What are the main network namespaces commands?

answer_side.text_content:
Network namespace management:

Create namespace:
sudo ip netns add mynetns

List namespaces:
ip netns list

Execute command in namespace:
sudo ip netns exec mynetns command
sudo ip netns exec mynetns bash

Move interface to namespace:
sudo ip link set eth1 netns mynetns

Connect namespaces with veth pair:
sudo ip link add veth0 type veth peer name veth1
sudo ip link set veth1 netns mynetns

Delete namespace:
sudo ip netns delete mynetns

information_side.text_content: How do you configure NFS server for file sharing?

answer_side.text_content:
NFS server setup:

Install NFS server:
sudo apt install nfs-kernel-server

Configure exports in /etc/exports:
/shared/data 192.168.1.0/24(rw,sync,no_subtree_check)
/home/user 192.168.1.100(rw,sync,no_root_squash)

Export the shares:
sudo exportfs -ra
sudo systemctl restart nfs-kernel-server

Check exports:
sudo exportfs -v
showmount -e localhost

Firewall (if needed):
sudo ufw allow nfs

information_side.text_content: What commands help with network packet analysis?

answer_side.text_content:
Packet analysis tools:

tcpdump -i eth0  (capture packets)
tcpdump -i eth0 port 80  (HTTP traffic only)
tcpdump -i eth0 -w capture.pcap  (save to file)
tcpdump -r capture.pcap  (read from file)

wireshark  (GUI packet analyzer)
tshark -i eth0  (command-line Wireshark)

ngrep -d eth0 "GET" tcp port 80  (grep for packets)
ss -i  (socket statistics with details)
netstat -anp  (active connections with processes)

information_side.text_content: How do you set up SSH agent for key management?

answer_side.text_content:
SSH agent management:

Start SSH agent:
eval $(ssh-agent)
# Or: ssh-agent bash

Add keys to agent:
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
ssh-add -l  (list loaded keys)

Remove keys:
ssh-add -d ~/.ssh/id_rsa  (remove specific key)
ssh-add -D  (remove all keys)

Automatic on login (add to ~/.bashrc):
if [ -z "$SSH_AUTH_SOCK" ]; then
  eval $(ssh-agent)
  ssh-add
fi

information_side.text_content: How do you configure UFW (Uncomplicated Firewall)?

answer_side.text_content:
UFW firewall configuration:

Basic commands:
sudo ufw enable  (enable firewall)
sudo ufw disable  (disable firewall)
sudo ufw status  (show current rules)
sudo ufw status verbose  (detailed status)

Allow/deny rules:
sudo ufw allow 22  (allow SSH)
sudo ufw allow ssh  (allow SSH by name)
sudo ufw allow 80/tcp  (allow HTTP)
sudo ufw deny 23  (deny telnet)
sudo ufw allow from 192.168.1.0/24

Delete rules:
sudo ufw delete allow 80
sudo ufw --force reset  (reset all rules)

information_side.text_content: What are the key files for persistent network configuration?

answer_side.text_content:
Important network configuration files:

/etc/network/interfaces  (Debian/Ubuntu traditional)
/etc/netplan/*.yaml  (Ubuntu 18.04+ with netplan)
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/  (CentOS/RHEL)
/etc/hosts  (hostname to IP mappings)
/etc/resolv.conf  (DNS configuration)
/etc/hostname  (system hostname)
/etc/nsswitch.conf  (name resolution order)
/etc/systemd/network/  (systemd-networkd)

NetworkManager config:
/etc/NetworkManager/NetworkManager.conf
/etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/

information_side.text_content: How do you configure IPv6 networking in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
IPv6 configuration:

Enable IPv6:
echo 0 > /proc/sys/net/ipv6/conf/all/disable_ipv6

Add IPv6 address:
ip -6 addr add 2001:db8::1/64 dev eth0
ip -6 route add default via 2001:db8::1

Show IPv6 info:
ip -6 addr show
ip -6 route show

IPv6 tools:
ping6 ipv6.google.com
traceroute6 ipv6.google.com
dig AAAA google.com  (IPv6 DNS lookup)

Automatic configuration:
sysctl net.ipv6.conf.eth0.accept_ra=1

information_side.text_content: What commands help with network load balancing and high availability?
How do you configure network QoS (Quality of Service) with tc?

answer_side.text_content:
Traffic control (tc) for QoS:

Add qdisc (queuing discipline):
tc qdisc add dev eth0 root tbf rate 1mbit burst 32kbit latency 400ms

Limit bandwidth:
tc qdisc add dev eth0 root netem delay 100ms
tc qdisc add dev eth0 root netem loss 1%

Class-based queueing:
tc qdisc add dev eth0 root handle 1: htb default 12
tc class add dev eth0 parent 1: classid 1:1 htb rate 100mbit
tc class add dev eth0 parent 1:1 classid 1:10 htb rate 80mbit ceil 100mbit

Show rules:
tc qdisc show dev eth0
tc class show dev eth0

information_side.text_content: How do you set up WireGuard VPN in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
WireGuard VPN setup:

Install WireGuard:
sudo apt install wireguard

Generate keys:
wg genkey | tee private.key | wg pubkey > public.key

Create config /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf:
[Interface]
PrivateKey = <private_key>
Address = 10.0.0.1/24
ListenPort = 51820

[Peer]
PublicKey = <peer_public_key>
AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.2/32
Endpoint = peer.example.com:51820

Start WireGuard:
sudo wg-quick up wg0
sudo systemctl enable wg-quick@wg0

information_side.text_content: What commands monitor network security and intrusion detection?

answer_side.text_content:
Network security monitoring:

Port scanning detection:
nmap -sS target_ip  (SYN scan)
nmap -sU target_ip  (UDP scan)
nmap -A target_ip  (aggressive scan)

Network monitoring:
arp-scan 192.168.1.0/24  (discover devices)
fail2ban-client status  (intrusion prevention)
rkhunter --check  (rootkit detection)
chkrootkit  (rootkit checker)

Log monitoring:
tail -f /var/log/auth.log  (authentication attempts)
journal -f _SYSTEMD_UNIT=ssh.service
lastb  (failed login attempts)
last  (successful logins)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network multicast in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Multicast configuration:

Enable multicast routing:
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/conf/all/mc_forwarding

Add multicast route:
route add -net 224.0.0.0 netmask 240.0.0.0 dev eth0
ip route add 224.0.0.0/4 dev eth0

Join multicast group:
smcroute -j eth0 239.1.1.1

Test multicast:
ping 224.0.0.1  (all systems multicast)
netstat -gn  (show multicast group memberships)

Tools:
mcjoin  (join multicast groups)
iperf3 -c 239.1.1.1  (multicast performance test)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network time synchronization?

answer_side.text_content:
Network time synchronization:

NTP configuration (/etc/ntp.conf):
server 0.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.pool.ntp.org iburst

Systemd-timesyncd (/etc/systemd/timesyncd.conf):
NTP=0.pool.ntp.org 1.pool.ntp.org
FallbackNTP=time.nist.gov

Commands:
timedatectl status  (show time sync status)
timedatectl set-ntp true  (enable NTP)
chrony sources  (chrony time sources)
ntpq -p  (NTP peer status)
date  (show current time)

information_side.text_content: What are the main commands for managing SSL/TLS certificates?

answer_side.text_content:
SSL/TLS certificate management:

Generate private key:
openssl genrsa -out private.key 2048

Create certificate signing request:
openssl req -new -key private.key -out request.csr

Self-signed certificate:
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365 -nodes

View certificate:
openssl x509 -in cert.pem -text -noout
openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 -servername google.com

Let's Encrypt:
certbot --nginx -d example.com
certbot renew

information_side.text_content: How do you configure and monitor network bandwidth usage?

answer_side.text_content:
Bandwidth monitoring and control:

Real-time monitoring:
iftop -i eth0  (interface traffic)
nethogs  (per-process bandwidth)
bandwidth  (command-line monitoring)
slurm -i eth0  (network statistics)
vnstat -i eth0  (historical usage)

Traffic shaping:
tc qdisc add dev eth0 root tbf rate 1mbit burst 32kbit
wonderland  (graphical traffic shaper)
trickle -d 50 -u 10 wget large_file  (per-process limiting)

Monitoring tools:
sar -n DEV 1  (network device statistics)
iptraf-ng  (network monitoring)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network logging and syslog?

answer_side.text_content:
Network logging configuration:

Rsyslog configuration (/etc/rsyslog.conf):
# Enable remote logging
*.* @@logserver.example.com:514

# Log iptables
kern.warning /var/log/iptables.log

Systemd journal:
journalctl -u systemd-networkd
journalctl -f --grep ssh
journalctl --since "1 hour ago" _SYSTEMD_UNIT=NetworkManager.service

Network service logs:
tail -f /var/log/syslog | grep dhcp
tail -f /var/log/auth.log | grep ssh
logger -p local0.info "Custom network message"

Log rotation:
/etc/logrotate.d/networking

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network bridges in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Network bridge configuration:

Create bridge:
ip link add name br0 type bridge
ip link set dev br0 up

Add interfaces to bridge:
ip link set dev eth0 master br0
ip link set dev eth1 master br0

Bridge utilities:
brctl addbr br0
brctl addif br0 eth0
brctl addif br0 eth1
brctl stp br0 on  (enable spanning tree)

Show bridge info:
bridge link show
brctl show
bridge fdb show  (forwarding database)

Remove from bridge:
ip link set dev eth0 nomaster

information_side.text_content: What commands help with network packet filtering and analysis?

answer_side.text_content:
Packet filtering and analysis:

Tcpdump filters:
tcpdump -i eth0 host 192.168.1.1
tcpdump -i eth0 port 80
tcpdump -i eth0 'tcp and dst port 443'
tcpdump -i eth0 icmp
tcpdump -i eth0 -w capture.pcap

Wireshark (text mode):
tshark -i eth0 -c 100
tshark -r capture.pcap -Y "http.request"

Advanced filtering:
tcpdump 'src net 192.168.1.0/24 and dst port 22'
tcpdump 'tcp[tcpflags] & tcp-syn != 0'
ngrep -d eth0 "GET" port 80

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network namespaces in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Network namespaces:

Create namespace:
ip netns add myns
ip netns list

Execute in namespace:
ip netns exec myns bash
ip netns exec myns ip addr show

Connect namespaces:
ip link add veth0 type veth peer name veth1
ip link set veth1 netns myns
ip netns exec myns ip addr add 10.0.1.2/24 dev veth1
ip netns exec myns ip link set veth1 up

Delete namespace:
ip netns delete myns

Network isolation:
unshare --net --uts /bin/bash

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for DHCP client and server management?
How do you configure network bonding (link aggregation) in Linux?

answer_side.text_content:
Network bonding configuration:

Load bonding module:
modprobe bonding

Create bond interface:
echo +bond0 > /sys/class/net/bonding_masters
echo 802.3ad > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/mode
echo 100 > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/miimon

Add slaves:
ifconfig eth0 down
ifconfig eth1 down
echo +eth0 > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/slaves
echo +eth1 > /sys/class/net/bond0/bonding/slaves

Bonding modes:
0 = balance-rr
1 = active-backup
2 = balance-xor
4 = 802.3ad (LACP)

Show bond status:
cat /proc/net/bonding/bond0

information_side.text_content: What commands help with network performance tuning and optimization?

answer_side.text_content:
Network performance tuning:

TCP tuning parameters:
echo 'net.core.rmem_max = 67108864' >> /etc/sysctl.conf
echo 'net.core.wmem_max = 67108864' >> /etc/sysctl.conf
echo 'net.ipv4.tcp_window_scaling = 1' >> /etc/sysctl.conf
echo 'net.ipv4.tcp_timestamps = 1' >> /etc/sysctl.conf

Interface optimization:
ethtool -G eth0 rx 4096 tx 4096  (ring buffers)
ethtool -K eth0 tso on gso on  (offloading)
ethtool -A eth0 rx on tx on  (flow control)

Congestion control:
echo cubic > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_congestion_control
sysctl -p  (apply sysctl changes)

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network access control with MAC address filtering?

answer_side.text_content:
MAC address filtering:

View MAC addresses:
arp -a  (ARP table)
ip neigh show  (neighbor table)
cat /proc/net/arp

iptables MAC filtering:
iptables -A INPUT -m mac --mac-source 00:11:22:33:44:55 -j ACCEPT
iptables -A INPUT -m mac --mac-source ! 00:11:22:33:44:55 -j DROP

Change MAC address:
ifconfig eth0 down
ifconfig eth0 hw ether 00:11:22:33:44:66
ifconfig eth0 up

Or with ip command:
ip link set dev eth0 address 00:11:22:33:44:66

MAC address tools:
macchanger -r eth0  (random MAC)

information_side.text_content: What are the essential commands for DNS troubleshooting and configuration?

answer_side.text_content:
DNS troubleshooting:

Basic DNS queries:
nslookup google.com
dig google.com
dig @8.8.8.8 google.com
dig google.com MX  (mail exchange records)
dig google.com NS  (name servers)
dig -x 8.8.8.8  (reverse lookup)

DNS configuration:
/etc/resolv.conf:
nameserver 8.8.8.8
nameserver 1.1.1.1
search example.com

Local DNS:
/etc/hosts:
192.168.1.10 server.local

DNS cache:
systemd-resolve --flush-caches
systemd-resolve --status

information_side.text_content: How do you configure network monitoring with SNMP?

answer_side.text_content:
SNMP configuration and monitoring:

Install SNMP:
sudo apt install snmp snmp-mibs-downloader

SNMP queries:
snmpwalk -v2c -c public localhost system
snmpget -v2c -c public localhost 1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0
snmpbulkwalk -v2c -c public localhost 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2

SNMPd configuration (/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf):
rocommunity public localhost
syslocation "Server Room"
syscontact "admin@example.com"

Network device monitoring:
snmpwalk -v2c -c public router_ip 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.10  (interface stats)

MIB browser:
snmptranslate -Td 1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0

information_side.text_content: What are the key commands for network troubleshooting and diagnostics?

answer_side.text_content:
Comprehensive network diagnostics:

Connectivity tests:
ping -c 4 google.com
traceroute google.com
mtr google.com  (continuous trace)
telnet host port  (port connectivity)
nc -zv host port  (netcat port scan)

Interface diagnostics:
ethtool eth0  (link status)
mii-tool eth0  (media info)
dmesg | grep eth  (kernel messages)

Network stack:
ss -tuln  (listening ports)
lsof -i  (network connections)
netstat -rn  (routing table)
ip addr show  (interface info)
ip route show  (routes)

Performance:
iperf3 -s  (server mode)
iperf3 -c server_ip  (client test)
